awd_titl_txt: Improving Undergraduate Research Experiences for STEM Majors and Pre-Service Teachers via Berkeley Undergraduate Research Evaluation Tools (BURET)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Berkeley Undergraduate Research Evaluation Tools (BURET) project will explore how undergraduate research experiences (UREs) in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) help students develop an understanding of scientific research. Across the U.S., many students engage in UREs each year, and universities dedicate substantial resources to supporting these programs. However, there are relatively few studies about the benefits for students in terms of their learning gains. In response to this deficiency, the BURET project will develop methods to track STEM undergraduate learning in UREs, study how participating in UREs prepares pre-service teachers to guide K-12 students in inquiry-based learning, and develop materials to train graduate students and postdoctoral researchers to be effective mentors to undergraduate research students. The results from this work will provide evidence for improving existing STEM education and teacher education programs, and broadening support for undergraduate research. 

The BURET project will study and improve UREs through the following specific aims: (1) Develop, refine, and test tools to assess how students integrate understanding of scientific practices and content while participating in UREs, (2) characterize how undergraduate researchers and pre-service teachers develop an integrated understanding of scientific practices and content over time, and (3) explore interventions for improving learning of scientific practices and content for undergraduate researchers. The project will use a mixed methods approach with surveys, interviews, and observations to study both the outcomes of UREs for STEM majors and the effects of incorporating UREs in teacher education on inquiry-based K-12 teaching practices. The project team will share findings across STEM departments at UC Berkeley via periodic workshops to improve the structure, learning goals, and evaluation of UREs.  The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program is providing co-funding for this project in recognition of its alignment with the broader STEM pre-service teacher education research goals of the Noyce effort.

por.por_cntn:
Undergraduate students majoring in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) frequently work in laboratories and with research groups at their universities to learn more about science concepts and cutting-edge research practices. These undergraduate research experiences (UREs) include pre-service teachers, who bring what they learn to their future K-12 students in science and math classrooms. Because university leaders and faculty debate the value of allocating scarce resources to these activities, understanding the impact of UREs is crucial. 

This project focused on developing the Berkeley Undergraduate Research Evaluation Tools (BURET), designed to evaluate the learning outcomes of UREs in chemistry and other STEM fields, and among undergraduates who are headed to graduate school or industry in their fields as well as future STEM teachers. This project focused on supporting and assessing undergraduate researchers and their graduate student mentors by: (1) developing and testing tools to assess student integration of scientific practices and content while participating in UREs, (2) characterizing how chemistry undergraduate researchers and pre-service teachers develop an integrated understanding of scientific practices and content, and (3) exploring the impact of graduate student mentor training workshops. 

We developed new assessment tools that directly analyzed research products, measured mastery of scientific content or research practices, and probed graduate students? perspectives on their teaching and mentoring practices. These assessment tools are able to detect how undergraduates connect their understanding of (1) the significance of their project, (2) experimental design, (3) analysis and interpretation of data, and (4) future experiments. We found that these instruments distinguished between novice and advanced undergraduate researchers and identified strengths and weaknesses in the development of undergraduate researchers. First-year students excelled at explaining the societal relevance of their work, but they incorporated only minimal discussion of prior scientific research into their reflections and presentations. Students at all levels struggled to critique their own experimental design. These results have important implications for undergraduate learning, suggesting areas for faculty members, graduate student research mentors, and URE programs to improve undergraduate research experiences. Although this research was primarily carried out in chemistry, we successfully used the tools with students in other STEM fields.

Additionally, we created and held a 5-part summer workshop series for graduate students and postdoctoral mentors who work with diverse undergraduate researchers to develop effective undergraduate teaching and mentoring practices. The interactive curriculum included strategies for probing what undergraduate understand about their projects, guidance for reading primary research literature, and fostering independence. In total, approximately 100 STEM graduate student mentors completed the summer workshop series over 4 years. To explore outcomes, multiple types of data were collected that solicited mentors? descriptions of their teaching and mentoring goals, and their perceptions of how their teaching and mentoring practices changed and how their undergraduates developed as researchers. Results from analyzing this data indicated that graduate students who completed the BURET workshop series learned and applied a range of inquiry-based teaching and mentoring practices for supporting undergraduate researchers, periodically assessed learning of their undergraduate mentees, and benefitted from a teaching/mentoring community.

Broader impacts of this project include its intersection with K?12 education by engaging and assessing CalTeach pre-service teachers engaged in STEM research. We found that CalTeach graduates who did undergraduate STEM research used what they learned when teaching their own middle and high school students how to do science experiments and solve complex mathematical problems. Note that CalTeach successfully recruits a diverse population of future teachers; in 2018-19 approximately 81% were from non-white populations compared to 26% or 48% of entering teachers in the nation or state. Additionally, CalTeach pre-service teachers and graduates serve a large and extremely diverse population of students in California?s urban Bay Area and rural Central Valley. Finally, we have joined several other universities in forming the Collaborative Around Research Experiences for Teachers (CARET), which resulted in a comprehensive review of literature from the field. Other broader impacts include development of the Computational Chemistry for Transfer Students (CC-TS) program, which introduces transfer students (who are a key contributor to the demographic diversity of UC Berkeley and STEM majors) to undergraduate research.
